content: H.R. 3962, Affordable Health Care for America Act, passed by the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009, is based on H.R. 3200. The Congressional Budget Office estimates the bill would reduce federal deficits by $109. The CBO estimates that H.R. 3962 would reduce federal deficits by $109 billion over 10 years and insure 96% of the non-elderly, legally present U.S. population by 2019. The total cost of Exchange subsidies, increased federal Medicaid expenditures, and tax credits for small employers would be $1.052 trillion. The net cost of the coverage provisions, including Exchange subsidies, federal Medicaid expenditures, and tax credits for small employers, would be $891 billion over 10 years. This cost would be offset by other spending changes, resulting in a reduction of federal deficits by $109 billion. The Affordable Health Care for America Act, passed by the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009, includes provisions to reduce the number of uninsured, restructure the private health insurance market, set minimum health benefit standards, and provide financial assistance.
